discussion.content:
E. Do a force stop
F. Clear the application cache GOOD ANSWER AGREE WITH COMPTIA

Force-stopping an application is like a “nuclear” option because it immediately halts all processes related to a specific application. This can be useful if an application is not responding or causing issues, but it also means that any unsaved work in that application could be lost. But same can happen with option A.... I gonna have to go with E and F
I'm thinking force stop may delete any unsaved work. I don't think options A and F will be as nuclear as force stops.

E. Do a force stop
F. Clear the application cache
Should be D and F? What is a force stop

comments.content: Agree, Read this article to understand why you should force stop and clear cache : https://www.androidauthority.com/force-stop-clear-cache-746645/

If you reinstall the app, there is no point in clearing its cache.
Force stop is what it is, it forces the application to stop running so that it can be terminated.

The question also states "not lose any critical information" so reinstalling it would be incorrect.
Force stop and clearing its cache is the best solution.

questions.question_text: A customer is having issues with an Android-based smartphone after a recent application update. The application becomes unresponsive immediately after attempting to open it. Auto-sync is not enabled, and no recent backups exist for the smartphone. Without losing any critical information, which of the following should be performed NEXT to further troubleshoot the issue? (Choose two.)

A new user has joined a company, and human resources has given the user several documents to sign regarding compliance and regulations for company computers. The user has also received web links to documentation for applications, as well as processes and procedures to do jobs in accordance with those programs. Which of the following types of documentation has the user MOST likely received? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: If you read the first part of the question it sounds like Acceptable Use Policy and the second part sounds like Knowledge Base Articles. Most of this test is figuring out the exact wording references

AUP Stands for "Acceptable Use Policy." An AUP is list of rules you must follow in order to use a website or Internet service. It is similar to a software license agreement (SLA), but is used specifically for Internet services.

Or how the company wants you to use their computers

comments.content: End-User Acceptance falls under Change Management, not employees

End user acceptance is the step before closing a ticket, so is related to a change 

When an employee receives a laptop, no ticket is open, so end user acceptance doesn't apply. 
On a laptop assignment, succeed acceptable use policy to inform what is or is not allowed on the use of the device

questions.question_text: An administrator is investigating intermittent, slow performance of a web server. The administrator performs a virus scan on the server but finds there is no infection present. Which of the following should the administrator do NEXT to mitigate the issue?

discussion.content: Wrong choice of word (mitigate) but the correct answer is to check the logs to see what is occurring. There is nothing to indicate that the server is using spinning HDs as storage which would benefit from defragmentation.
Always check the logs first. Use the logs to decide what course of action is necessary.
It should be D. Question asks an action "to mitigate" the issue.

comments.content:
Admittedly it is a poorly worded question but how do you know there is fragmentation on the disk yet? Event viewer if the best first step as this will allow us to find what is actually causing the problem, can't mitigate if you don't know the cause.

In fact it doesn't even mention if it's an HDD or SSD, if it's an SSD then you shouldn't have to defrag it anyway.

Defragmenting HDDs improves performance because it moves pieces of files so they are next to each other on the physical disk and the platter doesn't have to keep moving position to find the next piece of data.

SSDs have access to any part of their storage without any physical movement so defragmenting an SSD will not have any discernible effect on performance. In fact a lot of people reccomend NOT to defrag an SSD because they have a finite amount of write cycles in their lifetime and defragmenting would use up write operations for no benefit.

discussion.content:
netstat -p TCP
Displays the connections for the specified protocol, in this case TCP (also possible: UDP, TCPv6, or UDPv6)
netstat - Command-line tool in Windows and Linux to identify inbound and outbound TCP/IP connections with the host.

questions.question_text: A technician is using a CLI to perform tasks on a Windows OS. The technician needs to determine which ports are being utilized for TCP listening. Which of the following commands should the technician use?

A technician has been asked to recommend antivirus software for a home PC, but the user does not want to pay for a license.
Which of the following license types should the technician recommend?

discussion.content:
The answer is correct, it is open license.
OBJ-4.6: An open license or free license is the legal statement that allows free content and free software to be free. Since the customer doesn't want to pay for a license, it is important that the user gets a word processing program that uses an open license so that they do not have to pay for their software. For example, OpenOffice is an open license-based software that provides a word processor that can be used on Windows, Linux, or OS X for free.

comments.content: Betty where are you getting that info? I am loving every question you comment on

discussion.content: I think they meant Open Source License.

Open license is not the same as open source. Similar to Linux in the open license category, it's free. Open source allows you to chance the program itself. The license category depends on how you can use it and if there is a fee. The only one tha is completely free is the open license. With the others, the company that developed the program requires you to pay for its services either as a recurring bill or a one time payment. For example, Windows Defender vs Norton. You pay for Norton but not Defender.

I think what CompTIA means is that Open source as in you or a community can modify the program. There are free anti-malware for free and technically it's a close source... All I can say to anyone is what CompTIA thinks the right answer is rather than the real world.

comments.content:
Open license is free for anyone to access and use. This is the industry definition.
Personal license is paid (or free depending on available features and vendor) for an individual to use. For example consider AVG, they have 2 stages to their personal license. The opening license you receive on opening the software allows anybody to use scanning and antivirus only but only after paying for the full personal license do you get all features such as firewall controls, Webguard and the like. The software itself does not change nor does the base functionality.

discussion.content: Does open licence mean open source? Antivirus software for personal use is generally personal licence. It's free because the data collected is used to improve the Antivirus product. There is nothing open about the software. Even if there was an open source Antivirus project this question ignores personal licence Antivirus software. Experiences don't match CompTIA, ahhh!
